0GXFgxmc-90b_ABSyZssuQ.text: I went here for lunch with a couple of coworkers because we saw their $8.99 lunch special.  It was well advertised, and they got us to go.  The $8.99 special comes with a choice of Cesar or mixed house salad, choice of pasta (from 4 choices), and a dessert (with no choice).  They also serve complimentary bread in the beginning which is always nice.  SO the funny thing is that they serve all 3 portions (salad, pasta, and dessert) all on the same plate!  It was cool in a way, BUT the portions were way too small.  So i had to eat extra bread to feel full!    I got ordered:   House salad: I got the balsamic dressing (FYI, this was a thicker kind of balsamic dressing) everything about the salad was acceptable.    Penne Vodka pasta:  It was very good, but the portion was too small.    Cheesecake:  I am not sure everyday it is cheesecake for the lunch special.  It was great cheesecake, but once again a very tiny portion.   I am not holding them against their tiny portions for their lunch special because we took a risk to try it.  The one thing that brought them down to 3 stars was their lack of service for refilling our sweet teas, and bringing our check just very slow during lunch time.  Other then that I would definitely go back for the normal large portions of food!  ENJOY!

He continued to go out of convenience because of proximity to the office, but after his last experience, he will never Aria again. 91Tellb2d5cpbuNFEpZmoA.text: While visiting Charlotte on a business trip, we discovered Aria. I had the mushroom risotto and the caprese insalata. The risotto was amazing!! One of the best I have ever had. The caprese is kind of a deconstructed plate but it didn't make it any less good. I loved the basil and the buratta. My co worker had the trout and loved it as well. Bread is served before dinner with a bean salad instead of butter or a dip (different idea but it was ok.) The concept of this restaurant is to provide a casual environment which I absolutely loved but, wine was served in a low ball type glass and wine should always be served in a wine glass. Overall, a great experience and looking forward to it again! Staff was friendly, welcoming and provided some great recommendations for our trip!

lyvC3wPfFAjb6yaZ0jxnEg.text: One of my favorite spots for Happy Hour! They have bar bites available on weekdays, and usually serve some type of drink special.   The carmelized gnocchi is outstanding, the sliders range from very good to delicious, (flavors rotate often,) and the wild mushroom goat cheese pizza has tons of flavor!   The calamari are not as good as some which I've had, and the rings are very small.   Not a fan of the desserts, but I like supersweet desserts, and none of theirs are.  A great place to come with friends, family, or for a romantic dinner.  Even though the setting is upscale the environment is casual. Staff ranges from helpful to helpfully friendly, and valet eliminates the uptown parking headache.

4Ij0sp-nYLlNKPQuOLryKQ.text: This is a classy, delicious restaurant in Uptown Charlotte.  I've dined here for both special occasions as well as casual dinners at the bar.  The food is always delicious and the unique wine selection is impressive.   You can get away with dolling up or dressing casually...great ambience!  The bartenders are sweethearts and make incredible Moscow Mules (in copper mugs).  Look for the daily wine glass selection - it's probably something unique and wonderful!  Meals start with warm, fresh bread with a white bean, garlic, and olive oil dip.  Try the Lamb Pappardelle!  It's my go-to and never disappoints.   Beyond the dinner menu, they offer a Bar Bites selection of small plates.  A few of these with friends (or solo) will fill you up while you enjoy the bar.  I've been here when they've had great live music (acoustic guitar and singing).   ...and they have Gentlemen Jack!

GUgerSl5pCDN6KxgfFco4g.text: My friend and I went to aria last night and the food was GREAT! We did the restaurant week deal and I got the caprese for an app-- their pesto was on point! Then penne a la vodka as my entree which was equally as amazing! But the best part of the meal was the marscapone cheesecake which was absolutely phenomenal! For drinks I had a derby day which was a whiskey mixed with earl grey which was really good, and a glass of the Cielo Pinot noir. JglDnNIaY7KbLS4zuLxGIQ.text: I've been here for lunch several times and I tend to bring business partners here for working lunches. With that said, today I dined at Aria with a peer and from the moment the waiter (a young male with dark hair) was pushing appetizers to us. vzTniSq15Le8XKj481qehg.text: AMAZING place, all around! Beautifully decorated restaurant and bar! The food & drinks were out of this world! I had the Limoncello Slam, kale Brussels sprout salad & HOMEMADE spaghetti & meatballs! Even the bread was awesome! Very happy & will be returning!

47QI0mBhM2U2eieAqB4FlA.text: Grabbed some dinner to go here after arriving in Charlotte a bit after most restaurants close (so early relative to New York!). Decided to order the Spiced Pork Belly and Pear & Goat Cheese Salad. After just 10 minutes, my food was done. True to Southern hospitality, the whole staff was incredibly kind.  The food however was just okay. The Spiced Pork Belly was a bit bland (maybe because I am used to Asian-style pork belly) and the brussel sprouts could have used a little more flavor. The Pear & Goat Cheese Salad was equally unimpressive, though they did give a lot of it as just an appetizer. I tend to prefer fresher pears in my salad and the pears here had been marinated for longer or something. The goat cheese was a bit too much to my taste, but I did enjoy the nuts and tangy dressing. Winner of the meal goes to the massive chunk of bread, which I was planning on not eating, but after taking a bite, finished almost all of it. It was still warm and soft on the inside with a crunchy crust. Delicious!  Nothing out of the ordinary about Aria, but if I happen to need a late dinner with friendly service in Charlotte again, I'd stop by and possibly try some of the entrees that my fellow Yelpers are raving about.

4lxruCrFw0YQQjemkRj0yg.text: Paul's Yelp Elite Rating: 4.25 Stars  Yet another excellent lunch at Aria. My co-worker recommended their Burger. I said, "Burger, at Aria?" Well low and behold they DO have a burger, and my God is it DAMNED GOOD!!! It's called the "Aria Burger" and sure enough it is on the menu.  Like most people who go for lunch, Aria has a great lunch special where they offer 3 courses for under $10 (usually). And that's typically what I've gotten....or, some of their traditional Italian fare, just not a Burger.  But my oh my, their Aria Burger is at least a good 1/2 pounds of freshly ground meat (don't know the blend), with Carmelized Onions, Mushrooms, Applewood Bacon, Cheddar Cheese and a Fried Egg with Truffled Aioli. I mean, how can this NOT be delicious? Oh, and mine also had some fresh Thyme in there because I could definitely taste the herb (which was yummy).  They prepare the meat however you want it, even rare if you dared. But I like my Burgers perfectly medium and it came out perfectly medium. This was a VERY JUICY burger, and it dripped all over my hands (the way I like it)! Hell my only criticism is that they should bring out those "hot towels" like they do in many Japanese steak houses to get that burger juice off you. But hey, I'm just nit picking. And parts of my burger's bun were a TAD hard/chewy.  But overall this is definitely one of THE BEST BURGERS in Uptown! I'm glad I listened to my colleague (who I normally do NOT listen to by the way - LOL). Well he was 1000% RIGHT on that call!  Definitely a Thumbs UP, especially for a great lunch!

xCGUfdyOkHZ7RqY1CQJd6w.text: You won't regret dining at Aria. I have tasted their (dinner entrees) veal, lasagne, and fettuccine. It's all about high quality ingredients that are delicious.  The dining area is beautiful. The rather large bar area is very upscale and hopping. The service is fast, not rushed but fast. The wine list is extensive and offers a large number of reds.   A very nice touch is the large chilled bottle of water that is brought to the table. It's Charlotte tap water in an unmarked bottle but it is a better option than the typical glass of ice water. It's just a nicely-thought-out small touch.  One last mention about the veal. So often you will find veal that is just so-so. The veal at Aria was the best that I have eaten. It was soft enough to cut with a fork. Served with a delicious lemon butter and with capers. Just great!  The kitchen is visible through a large window that runs across the back of the dining room. The cooking space is first class. The chefs are neatly dressed and move with precision and grace.

SoB82J5bOfTNjX785rG1nQ.text: Ok.  I ate at Aria two nights ago for a girlfriends Bachelorette party.  We had a party of 20 or so ladies.  For such a very big table, I was BAFFLED that there was only one waiter, but he did a spectacular job!  We felt like everything came out in a timely manner!  I had two drinks; "The peel" and the "DSL"... both were creative and delicious, but the peel was more grapefruit juice than cocktail... so I'm not sure the $8-10 pricetag was warranted for something that fit into a champagne flute.  The arugula and pear salad was delightful and the Scottish salmon was buttery and perfectly cooked!  I cannot say enough about how lovely the food was!  All in all - I paid just about $55 for two drinks, a salad, my meal, and a generous tip.  I don't think it's too much for a nice night out!  Compared to some of the other "upscale" restaurants in uptown Charlotte, I'd say you could do MUCH worse than a visit to Aria.  I thoroughly enjoyed it, and would go again!

_wPFo8g1iladpPlPNAaYwA.text: Working lunch delight!  This restaurant is a great lunch spot with co workers. All around a great place.  Atmosphere:  very comfortable and classy. i0z29pLq0gNHTVqlf4Z_9Q.text: Oh Aria I might have set my expectations a bit too high for you during restaurant week. They weren't terribly booked or busy when I went in on Thursday with my friends but we still got ignored for quite a good while by the hostess. It's not like we looked like bums or anything everyone was dressed up for a nice night out and were excited, we had even made reservations so it was slightly upsetting to get walked by without even a greeting when we walked in.  Hostess aside after we got seated the servers were quite competent and explained that the whole menu was available to order from during restaurant week. Awesome! The ice cold bean spread they serve with the bread while you peruse the menu is blech, I ended up just putting some olive oil on my plate and dipping it in that with some salt and pepper. I started with the caramelized gnocchi, delicious! Slightly crisp on the outside and just a hint of char from the caramelization. The Osso Bucco followed up but failed to deliver and actually kind of disappointed me a bit. Way overcooked, too much acid in the layer of chard underneath, but the polenta was nice and creamy, rich and flavorful I wish there was more of it. Hearing great things about the chocolate hazelnut cake, I decided to go for it. Well it was a bit too sweet for me and pretty average on my cake scale to be honest. Going with four people I also got to try out a lot of stuff that my friends ordered. I'd stay away from the crab cake, lots of crab but it didn't taste fresh at all more fishy. I think the way they pace meals was quite perfect, courses were brought out in a timely manner which doesn't always happen during crw so I appreciate that.  The ambiance here is quite wonderful, the food seems to be hit or miss which is not quite acceptable to me considering the prices you'll be paying here. I might go here on a whim again sometime. Hopefully they'll have less snotty hostesses and some of the kinks worked out in the food because I really want to like this place more.

MU3qajooy7f1GkOl7z7kNA.text: Really 3.5 stars.  I went with my wife on a Friday evening around 8, no reservation, no problem getting a table.  It seemed to get a little crowded after a Bobcats game let out later on, but it was fine.  The service was without any problems, unlike many of the reviews here.  Of course, we were at a table not at the bar.  It is a bit trendy, but not unbearably so.  The food is good.  I loved the warm ciabatta type roll that came out first, with some olive oil and pepper it was a great appetizer.  We also had the fritti mixti.  I had originally asked about the 5 dollar bar bites, but evidently they are only available at the bar.  The mixti was fine, but nothing special for 12 dollars.  We had two glasses of wine, which sort of bizarrely arrived in normal tumbler style glasses rather than wine glasses.  I didn`t really care, but it was a first for me.  For an entree I had the sausage, broccoli rabe and orrechiette, with a very strong garlic flavor (plus in my book) and a good bit of spice.  I have dairy issues, so it would have been nice if they had listed the cheese in the ingredients on the menu.  Nonetheless, it was flavorful.  My wife had the bucatini with pesto which she also like quite a good deal.    We had a good meal, but I don`t think that we will be back.  It is a bit costly for what they offer, and it is definitely too trendy for us.  It looks like it is trying to attract an epicenter crowd.

c0ACkeNsMmp5N91UXCiznw.text: Love it when a expensive, hyped  restaurant lives up to the reputation.  We went during restaurant week, so expected the quality to take a hit while they were feeding the hungry masses...soooo wrong! Im stingy with my 5 stars but I just could not find a thing wrong.  The cauliflower soup was silky and delicate with interesting flavors, the lamb shank was so  incredibly delicious and flavorful, the desserts were AMAZING- blueberry upside down cake was warm, yummy soft cake with local blueberrys and ice cream, the almond brittle cheesecake was so good!. LOVED Aria, its now on my top 5 in Charlotte.

BF1yiBZxsgCuoxRlpao4zw.text: I wanted to love this place since its got a great spot uptown and great ambiance inside! For the main dish I ordered the Pasta al Nero. It was doused in sauce to cover up a poor tasting noodle. The shrimp on the pasta was great. Portion was small.   Our dessert took ~30 minutes to come out... kind of frustrating when you just ordered a gelato... just scoop it out of the carton and bring it out please. When we let our waiter know how long we had waited, he said it was coming soon, and then walked away to continue to serve his other tables. Never went to the kitchen to check on or dessert. The server seemed pretty inexperienced, he would always forget to bring out drinks out.. the bartender/ some sort of manager would bring them over because they sat on the bar for too long. aQslfCXnrX0yVc6-sPbu_Q.text: Nice decor, fast service, and lots of options on the lunch and dinner menus.  I've been here a dozen or more times and have never been disappointed.  It's also a must-visit during Charlotte Restaurant Week because they include their full menu, and the food and service are just as good as any other time.  They have a lunch combo with a salad, entree, and dessert.  All are small portions but it's perfect for lunch.  I love their penne a la vodka and get it just about every time.   If you sit at the bar, they have a few options for appetizers that are not available in the dining room, like their pork belly.  I love the way Aria makes this dish, and it's well worth it to sit here at least once to try it!  Service at the bar is also excellent.   Some of our favorite entrees are the scallop/mushroom/artichoke risotto, the meat ragu pappardelle, and spaghetti and meatballs.  The scallop dish is one of my favorites at any Charlotte restaurant - it's literally BURSTING with flavor.   I'm not a big drinker, but their blueberry martinis are fantastic.  I usually get two and make my hubby drive home.  Aria is one of my favorite places for a nice dinner.  With consistently good food and service, I always leave full and happy.

K9j59kUp62HN9pEcynM8WQ.text: I call this review, High Hopes and Bubble Nightmares.   I too went to a benefit here, which is completely separate to how in feel about the Bubble Lounge. The organization I was there supporting, couldn't be nicer...but the lounge needs some serious work.   Having it be part of Aria, you know it's going to be trendy.  The circular bar is nicely set up, as is the rest of the lounge. The finishes are rich and it feels modern and sleek.    The problem my friends and I had was the service, or lack of it. We waited a good, 10, 15 minutes at the bar, and watched as the staff served champagne to the other ladies around us, but ignored us as we BLATANTLY HELD OUT OUR HANDS WITH DRINK TICKETS. It was almost like being in middle school again.  Ignored by the cool kids.   When passed apps came around, that's what they did.  The servers with trays walked around, and didn't stop at our section of the bar.  When FINALLY a tray of mini crabcakes was set down, we each took one, and immediately, the server took it back.    There were also no napkins passed at this time, so my friend and I at one point were left with a skewer of lamb...and left the sticky skewer on the bar.  Classy.   The passed coconut shrimp was ok...but reminded me of a soggier version of that Margaritaville frozen coconut shrimp in the supermarket freezer section.   The creme de la creme...  I was sitting at the bar chair, and when the phyllo-wrapped asparagus came around, I stood up (butt still touching the seat of the chair) to get one. I felt something behind me, almost sat down, but REALIZED THERE WAS NO CHAIR UNDER ME!   A woman had taken it from under my bottom!  I looked over her, asked her why she did it, and she, along with her smug boyfriend/manfriend said "you stood up, so it's mine". (Or something to that extent.)   The manfriend then proceeded to hug the bartender who saw the entire situation go down.   One server was kind to us, but he was serving Aria, so we didn't deal with him much...which brings me to the conclusion the Bubble Lounge has some serving issues to deal with.    In my book, it's all about service.  I don't care who you are, you could be my grandma, a supermodel, a TV news anchor or unemployed.  If you don't serve everyone equally, you've lost my service.   I may try this place again...but it's going to take a lot of improvement.

onV3WOveWAYwSdJsI6WtCw.text: Good gluten free dining option for the  menu savvy.  There is no separate gluten free menu, gluten free items are not designated on the menu and our waiter had no knowledge of what was and was not gluten free.  He was very willing to speak to the chef to find out :)  Our party of six dined here Wednesday night.  We were seated promptly.  Our waiter was friendly and efficient.  The dining room was somewhat loud but that was mostly due to our boisterous group!! Our appetizers consisted of the caramelized gnocchi (not gf), steamed mussels, and antipasto.   The steamed mussels were great, the gnocchi average and the antipasto not worth ordering again.  Our entrees were the Potato Gnocchi, Slate Grilled New york strip, Sausage Pizza, Chicken dish and the Osso Bucco.  According to our friends, the Pizza was really good and the chicken dish was fabulous.  The potato gnocchi (ordered by two diners) was average at best and not repeatable.  The new york strip was the least favorable of all the entrees our friend did not  care for it.  I ordered the Osso Bucco (deemed to be GF by the chef) and it was Out. Of. This. World.  Spot on flavor, falling off the bone, just absolutely FABULOUS. Deifnitely the best dish of our trip to Charlotte (after trips to Capital Grill, Dressler's and Bernardin's!).  For dessert our party ordered the Tiramisu, the Panna Cotta (deemed GF by the chef), and gelato over espresso.  All of these were good.  I really enjoyed the panna cotta!! JsVkmj9KjfBAMAgbo7gvoA.text: This new addition to Charlotte did a great job in exceeding our expectations on a recent snowy night.   Aria serves Tuscan food in a contemporary environment, and I loved that the open bar with live music that kept us entertained for most of the night.   We had a reservation at 9 on a Friday night. Good thing- as this place was packed! The restaurant is below street level so we were able to peek in as we walked along the sidewalk to gauge where we wanted to sit before walking in.   Upon entering the front door, you are in a vibrant bar with a wall of wine from floor to ceiling. Glancing around, the open kitchen is the next thing to catch your eye and then you spy the seating area as the tables are filled with animated people all enjoying their food while listening to the live guitar music. I could have sat in the bar all night- but dinner was our goal!   We were seated immediately and began to look at the menu. Our server, Carolyn was great! She knew the menu inside and out and was able to make some great suggestions for us. And the patrons were friendly too, as we struck up a conversation with the couple next to us within minutes of sitting down (but that's another story for another time)   We began with the tuna carpaccio and the antipasto plate. The tuna came with asparagus and was terrific, and the antipasto? Gone in an instant but not before enjoying the salami, olives and cheeses.   We decided to split a pasta and and a couple of entrees so that we could taste a larger range of the menu. The penne pasta with ricotta and vodka tomato cream sauce was perfection on a plate (would it have been wrong of me to lick the dish?). And the lamb chops were so good I didn't want to share them so my friend enjoyed his veal scallopini in peace.  Dinner for two with drinks and wine came to about $130 which was great considering the quality of the food and the quantity of the drinks that we had. It was a great night out and the service was spot on. We walked to the restaurant but if you are driving- they do have complimentary valet parking and also validate for the Bank of America parking garage.   Aria may be a new addition to Charlotte- but they have none of the new restaurant blues that so many places experience. Unless, of course you count the blues being played in the lounge, but on the night we were here- those were just the kind of blues we wanted to hear!

WMCb2uYY-peLCqPaDR4b9A.text: We seriously loved Aria. Let's start with the environment - the place is beautiful. The lighting is tasteful and fun. The bar is enormous, which is great for walk-ins. The open format allows for a relaxed but sumptuous atmosphere.   We sat at the bar, which was relatively empty considering it was 8pm on Saturday night (it was the night before Easter, so there were definitely a lot of folks out of town). We sat in the corner and started off with cocktails - a classic mojito and a lavender/vodka drink - both delicious. Their cocktails/wine/beer lists are all extensive and impressive. I probably would have tried any cocktail on the menu.  We skipped apps and just ordered entrees. We were given warm bread and traditional Italian white bean spread while we waited. I had pesto pasta, which was delicious. The pasta was fresh and the pesto was the perfect amount of nutty. My mom got the fancy steak (forgive me, as a vegetarian I don't remember the cut) and while she was disappointed at the size considering the price ($38 I believe), she said it was all delicious. We looked at the dessert menu but as chocolate lovers, nothing stuck out to us.   All in all, Aria is a great spot for those craving a fine-dining, NYC-esque experience. I will definitely be back, first for the cocktails, then for the food.

Our waiter seemed friendly enough at first (I can't remember his name, unfortunately) but it quickly became clear that he wasn't interested in serving us because of our age. We've had this happen a few times but it never gets old. Yes, my husband and I are in our mid- to late twenties but that does not mean that we aren't there to spend some money on a nice dinner. We are also great tippers if we are treated properly. The waiter was snippy with us and rarely checked on us. bIq5teDklMwsVJ4pVrNnkg.text: I went into Aria with mediocre expectations, as I do with all restaurants that boast "Tuscan" cuisine. But any reservations I came in with began to fall away right when I walked in the door. I also literally had no reservations. Who needs to call ahead on a Wednesday night to make a reservation for four people? You do, if you plan to come here. We were baffled at the crowd, but the host sprang to action and offered us the only table available - the "chef's table" - right in the kitchen. A "chef's table"? In Charlotte? We jumped right on it.    I headed to our special table with visions of hibachi restaurants, with chefs putting on a show. I was certain that it would be just a few moments until my girlfriend's and I were catching shrimp in our mouths, tossed from the cooks while singing and cheering, flames in the backdrop. I recently read an article from Charlotte Magazine in which the author described the Chef's table as a "small space off the dining room where they can enjoy dishes with commentary from the kitchen." Hmm. Commentary? At one point during dinner, one of my friends sneezed and I think - I think - one of the line cooks said "Bless you." Other than that, we kind of felt like we were intruding, and within five minutes we were all sweating like a group of menopausal women.   Anyway, once we cracked the menu we forgot we were in the kitchen. Everything sounded delicious and, between the four of us, it's safe to say that no one's dish disappointed. We ordered the bruschetta and, as Stephen said, it wasn't what we had pictured but once the first bite was taken, nobody cared anymore. We also had the eggplant parmigiana, equally delish. The bread was pretty average, and the white bean dip that came with it took it up a few notches. For entrees, we ordered the Wild Mushroom Pizza (very good,) the potato gnocchi (tasty), and the butternut squash ravioli. This last dish was a bit sweet, but soooooooooo good - I was craving it again the next day.  Overall, great experience here. Again, I agree with Stephen that there is nothing that indicates it is a "new" restaurant in terms of quality and service.

My main course was New York strip, medium rare which was served with potato pancetta hash, doesn't sound great , but it was perfect and the steak was cooked perfectly.  Dessert was a well made and testy cheesecake.  First of all,  the food was perfect,  the wait staff was on the ball and nice.  Secondly, I can't wait to go back and try other dishes until I've tried them all.  Take your cash because it is pricey.  A date for two with meal and cocktails will run you at least $120 at the low end, $180 is probably about average.  Well worth it if you don't mind the cost.  You will not be disappointed.

N1-UqCbJ27dXxlTzeyYLcg.text: First of all, it was Valentines Day and they had a fixed menu. That rarely excites wherever you are. But we'd never been and wanted a nice evening out. This place is NOT on Tryon. It was on East Trade.  Apparently they know this, have received complaints about this, but have done nothing about correcting the address.  We went early and it good thing we did as it was not very noisy while we dined, but downright loud when we left. The service was good- very attentive, maybe even it bit too much as at one point I felt rushed.  We had mussels and caprese for our appetizers. Tasty enough, but the mussels were big, a few didn't open and the wine sauce was cool.  The caprese was disappointing with no fresh tomato, only a dollop of burratta, too much pesto and a couple slivers of sun dried tomatoes.  The bread was awesome with the garlic infused olive oil and white beans.  We split the fettuccini carbonara.  It was served with a soft boiled egg on top, the ham tasted like Smithfield and the cream sauce was just ok.  We prepare carbonara at home, and frankly, for us, it far exceeds Aria's rendition.  The chicken Parmesan was ok - we skipped the pasta and substituted it with braised kale. I'm sorry, I still expected some marinara type sauce on my chicken and while my husband gobbled up the kale, i disliked it. The crispy chicken parm was achieved by using essentially tasteless panko bread crumbs.  While overall it was an ok evening, I am still looking for a fabulous Italian restaurant in Charlotte.

SLACBmA6mKkSthSJgRkBaw.text: I had a very disappointing experience at Aria. Which is unfortunate because I've been wanting to try it out for a couple of months. FP-GBgvBwUWGAd4JIXt4fQ.text: I'll start by saying we came here with a very large group on a Saturday night. We had called ahead to make reservations and this place did great handling our group.   Now, I had never been to this restaurant prior to this visit and didn't know what to expect. The one thing I noticed about this place is that no one is in a hurry. After waiting a while we met our waiter and ordered drinks. I didn't feel like alcohol so I ordered a Diet Coke. When the waiter returned, I was handled a very small bottle of soda. Why!? If you have read any of my previous reviews, one of my biggest pet peeves is not free refills and serving these tiny little bottles is their way to not give free refills. This place had already lost a star in my rating system.   After looking over the menu I went with the cheapest meal, the spaghetti and meatballs. At 14 bucks this better be some spectacular spaghetti and meatballs. When they brought it out the first thing I noticed was the small portion. Not much pasta and very small meatballs, not what I pictured from an Italian restaurant.   I'm not sure how they prepare the meatballs but it seemed to me as if they are precooked and then thrown onto a grill to reheat.  A couple were left on one side a little too long and the taste of char overwhelmed the other flavors.  While just eating the pasta the sauce actually had very good flavors and I felt the pasta was cooked perfectly.   Overall an ok place. Maybe with smaller parties they are faster with drinks and the food. But please get a soda fountain, I promise it will lower your costs and mine.

The server was friendly--kept butting into our conversation which seems like an odd thing to do at a location like this where people are clearly having business lunches (and this was was actually reserved as a birthday celebration)--but one of the fellas encouraged it so I can't fully blame the server.  The pacing was decent--definitely not the best as we kept having to ask for things (bread, drinks) and remind the server about things (condiments, napkins)--as we were paid and out in time to get to known meetings.  Not bad since some ordered a la carte salad + entree while others ordered the set menu which comes out all at once.  I'd go again for a business lunch but I really have no interest in doing this for dinner or at any other time.  The food just wasn't good enough to warrant it.

t0GGjOmLuf6qAPzRA50x-Q.text: Aria is second to Cafe Monte on my list of fancy-pants eatin' in the QC. My fiance and I go here for dinner any time we are catching some sort of show uptown. The food is always great and the service is very jovial and friendly.   I really don't think you can go wrong with anything on their menu; if it sounds good chances are it will be good. The cocktails are usually good; any 'off' drinks were more so because I just didn't enjoy the flavors as much as I thought I would (sometimes I try to be adventurous and it backfires). tMViv8okyCqjdQFkdButhA.text: Atmosphere: 5 Stars Staff and Service: 4 Star Reservations: 3 Stars Food: 3 Stars  It is really complicated review for myself. I have been a regular to Aria for almost 6 years now. What has been consistent about the place during those 6 year is simply how inconsistent the food is. Sometimes is great, sometimes is okay at best. Aria is not by any mean the best italian spot in Charlotte, but it is definitely one of the best despite their cons.   First, the decor is really great and cozy. The acoustic shows by local artists over the weekends totally makes a good atmosphere.   Second, since renovation, the place started to be overcrowded sometimes, which slow down the service, and definitely reduced the quality.  Third, the menu is well made. It is classic italian menu, with an interesting spin on some dishes. I am not going to review the food since it is very subjective to personal taste especially when it comes to italian cuisine, but for what it worth, overall the food is good, and you can clearly taste the quality of their ingredients. Any Wow factor? No really, but It is good enough after all.   You should try Aria at least once. If not for the food, just go for their bar menu/small plates as they will not disappointment you. As many have mentioned, service could be slow over the weekend, so I'd recommend visiting mid week, or during lunch hour.  Last thing, I truly love Aria, and I hope the owner/chef would take the reviews here seriously. The are many downsides that could be fixed if the ownership paid attention.

Z0kFTIKOKnKxtI1H8516QQ.text: Since I keep passing this place on my way to lunch everyday, I figured I had to try it out sooner or later. After I received two good recommendations about it, I decided it was finally time!  I went there last Friday with my co-workers and I will admit that I was pleasantly surprised. Not only was the food delicious, but the variety of items offered on the menu allows for an expansive Italian taste tour. My only reservation about Aria is in regard to the appetizers which, in my opinion are far too small to demand the price that they do. It's literally ONE crab cake for $12 and five tiny morsels of cheese also for $12. I found the caramelized gnocchi a bit "doughy," but the calamari is the best I've had this side of the country.  The entrees are definitely the selling points of this restaurant. The slow cooked beef short rib was tender, pink, juicy, and fatty! Osso Bucco and Angus Rib-Eye Filet were equally note-worthy. I'd say the red meat is their forte. Moreover, the portions suddenly quadruple in size once you get to the entrees such that you may as well skip out on the apps all together. My compatriots weren't raving about their chicken or pasta dishes and I came to the conclusion that their judgments were reasonable. "Tastes like chicken."  One aspect I particularly enjoyed about Aria was the attention placed on the garnishes for each dish. The tuna sashimi is served on a salt board, which flavors the meat as time passes (Don't wait too long though!). The "italian mac/cheese underneath the rib-eye is absolutely amazing (not overly-cheesy) and the garlic swiss chard on the Osso Bucco was relished by all.   I would definitely come here again to try more things on the menu. Perhaps I would pass on the apps this time because I would trade one entree for three apps any day of the week.  Yum!  4/5

Mz_FwT7VhB_yXyAOxMx8Dw.text: Went for a nice dinner out. We didn't drive there; keep in mind parking isn't really an option if you do. wJnPMVOE8olCpDAwPqTFSQ.text: I recently had dinner here with 3 other couples prior to a show at the Belk theater. The restaurant is conveniently located near the theater as well as the parking garage.  We had reservations for an early dinner around 5 pm, hardly anyone there and yet within the hour the restaurant was packed  The restaurant has a comfortable atmosphere and our waiter was friendly and attentive and answered our questions we had about the menu.  He poured water in tall glasses for us, readily took any other beverage orders. Interesting  to note that the individual glasses of Chianti  came in 1/2 filled short beverage tumblers and not typical  red wine glasses . Bread came to the table, was very delicious along with a tall bottle of Evoo plus some  small dishes of a tasty white bean condiment.  The menu features a variety of appetizers, several salads, a tomato basil soup, variety of pizzas, pasta dishes, other entrees to include chicken, lamb, beef and fish and seafood.. Desserts such as mascarpone cheese cake, cannoli  and tiramisu were on the menu  Prices moderate, portions adequate, food came out  hot, plated nicely, and most was tasty and delicious.   We all enjoyed our food. My dinner was  good but not exceptional in my opinion .Some of my dining mates also felt the same way about their dinners too.   One dining mate enjoyed her Caesar salad, plenty of dressing on it. I had the heirloom tomato caprese appetizer.  Plated, a wedge of soft delicious mozzarella surrounded by a  thin smear of basil pesto , (wished more of that) , along with small cubes of red tomatoes.  My dining mate had  one  of the appetizer specials of the night,  sliced duck breast  over focaccia with peaches and a savory sauce. . He said it was  very tasty.  3 of of us ordered the chefs version of chicken cacciatore, a very popular menu item.. We were able to substitute for the polenta it was normally  served over.  One substituted with pasta, mine with extra veges instead of the mascarpone polenta which the 3rd diner had.  Plated were 2 pieces of chicken nicely positioned on the plate. It was nice to see a piece of chicken with a bone instead of boneless chicken breast.  The chicken was tasty and nicely seasoned. My extra veges were mostly soupy stewed tomatoes . My dining mate said polenta was ok. The sauce was described with olives, capers and cremini mushrooms. The big green olives with pits were there, one or two  mushrooms in each order on our plates;  so for mushroom lovers a disappointment.  Other entrees our dining mates ordered were Grandma's lasagna, very much enjoyed, sliced lamb with gnocchi- tender lamb but heavy gnocchi however lamb enjoyed,  Pappardelle Rosso pasta which was noted as excellent, 2 orders of chicken parmesan also very much enjoyed.   One dining mate asked for his sauce on the side, so changes or substitutes readily done to please the diner.  For dessert, the canolli  was not enjoyed, the shell so tough it could not be cut with a fork, the filling very good. The waiter was notified and mentioned others  had the same complaint. The mascarpone cheesecake was very delicious. The coffee was also very good.  All in all it was a very enjoyable dining experience for us all.   We would probably return  and try ordering different dinners next time.

-B82iujrc1t60GGVT3z1LQ.text: I loved everything about Aria. The food was excellent, my server (Richard) was wonderful and the decor was beautiful. I stopped by on a Thursday evening after work to grab some dinner. The bar was getting pretty packed with men and women in suits and ties.  The menu looked good but the bar bites menu looked even better. Each plate was $5 and that was what sold me. I am always one who wants to try everything on the menu but my eyes are bigger than my stomach so I stuck to just three of the items. I ordered the caramelized gnocchi, beef short ribs and the bone marrow.   Before my orders were brought out I was presented with a small bowl of tuscan beans and a nice loaf of bread. It was crusty on the outside and soft and chewy on the inside. The beans were drizzled with olive oil and had a hint of lemon juice, salt, parsley, black pepper and salt. You eat the beans with the bread. I've never had this before and it was really good.  When my entrees came out they were beautifully plated and they tasted as good as they looked. My top favorite is the bone marrow. In close second was the beef short ribs and then the gnocchi. You scoop out the bone marrow, spread it on your buttered toast and top it off wit the veggies (parsley, red onions, capers). The beef short ribs were sitting on top of polenta and was topped with some greens (don't know what type) and what looked like cubes of beets. It was drizzled with a fruity, acidic sauce. The dish was pulled together nicely. The gnocchi was also beautifully plated but I got this only because it was a dish I have never had before. It looked like little balls of dough but did not taste doughy at all. It was soft and chewy but did not have much flavor. If it wasn't for the toppings (Prosciutto di Parma, Pear, Gorgonzola, Truffle Oil) I wouldn't have liked it.   I was pretty full at the end of my meal and didn't finish everything but wanted to get dessert to go. I opted for the chocolate Hazelnut Cake with Hazelnut Gelato & Vanilla Cream. Since I did not have a freezer in my hotel room for the gelato and ice cream, I had to get a substitute of berries. The slice of cake was pretty big and I could not finish it. The cake itself was a little dry but if you take in the hazelnut and the cake along with the chocolate together it is absolutely decadent. I would have been sinful if I had the ice cream and gelato too because I was told that it compliments the cake beautifully and brings out even more flavors. Ugh, I wish I had saved room to eat it the way it was supposed to be eaten. Oh well.

u_PsDPm5QqT40MPu6QLkeg.text: Aria is typically not the type of establishment I would frequent. It seems like the type of place that people who think they are sophisticated go to feel like they are sophisticated. As I'm fond of saying when I see tables VIP reserved at the booty clubs here in Charlotte, "This is not New York City."  Despite the Gattaca style ambiance that this troglodyte normally doesn't associate with Italian joints, the food was awesome. It does happen every so often that my ingrained, arbitrary, judgmental prejudices are incorrect.  This was a restaurant week visit and Aria gets automatic kudos for offering practically the full menu instead of paring the choices down to three or four almost popular options.  I did play it traditional with my meal, sticking to classic staples. The fried calamari was fresh, light and crispy, not greasy or oily at all, with plenty of tentacles, which are the best part. For my main entree, I had the linguine and clams like some kind of mafioso. Fresh clams in the shell and plenty of them served on a bed of al dente linguine and understated white wine clam sauce. The portion size thankfully is not overwhelming nor skimpy. All finished off with an amazing cheesecake, perhaps one of the best deserts I've ever had and I'm not a huge fan of cheesecake. Aria could be worth an end of the evening stop simply for desert. And I really don't believe in desert; it takes up too much stomach space that I need for meal gorging.  This three course dinner was not heavy at all like a lot of Italian food, sitting in your gut some sort of fart bomb ready to go off.  I did not get a drink, but the table next me ordered some refreshing looking cocktails. I'm comfortable enough with myself to drink pink. The wine selection is extensive. It's supposed to be, it's an Italian restaurant.  If I had a special lady, I'd take her here. Yeah, it's that nice.

-zMMVJaDeO2xEEBstXWrKA.text: Bravo Aria, Bravo.  From the beginning, Aria was a hit. I had heard it was good, so I had to go see for myself. Yep, it is.  We sat at the bar (although the best tables are in front on the kitchen) to try the best they had to offer. I am fairly confident that everything we didn't try would be excellent too! AwTLw8cDjKvTE8asOVkRuA.text: I was not expecting much from this place but was pleasantly surprised.  Went with a colleague on a Tuesday night -- it was decently busy but not packed.  We walked in w/o a reservation.  The server was pretty knowledgeable about the food and made good recommendations, including the gnocchi.  I'm very hard to please with gnocchi (ever since having THE BEST GNOCCHI EVER at Frasca in Boulder...but I digress).  I'm not sure why these guys put proscuitto in the gnocchi dish (kind of a wrapper) but it's hard to complain about proscuitto in just about any appetizer.  I ordered one of the nightly specials -- the suckling pig.  Honestly, it was good but could have been better.  I'm not sure how they did it but they managed to cook in dry in some parts but not in others.    I thought the wine list was reasonably priced.  I'm not sure why other reviewers complain that the selection was small.  I thought it was sufficient (I'm not a fan of the huge wine lists.)  We had a bottle of a pinot from Burgundy and it was tasty (lighter than the pinot noir I'm used to in Oregon....we finished our bottle and had a glass of a Willamette Valley p.n. that was even better.  Might have earned an additional half star except the server messed up my order and that made it take too long.  Plus, it's a bit over-priced...but ok for a special occasion or client dinner.

YOBHQnJHMXCO-haC6NQTHQ.text: I had a pretty good experience at this place, so let's get under way with some pro's-con's.  Some of my coworkers came down from NYC, so right off the bat, it was going to be a LBD kind of night. We began craving some good food around 930, so because they were staying at the Omni, all signs pointed to Aria. This was my first time going here.  It was pretty crowded (which is weird for any place in Charlotte at that time) so we had to wait maybe 5 minutes before we got seated. I was alright with that because I already had a few Jameson's in me, so all I really cared about was staying out of the cold. The waitress was phenomenal, never letting our glasses go dry. This was really spectacular because by that point, I couldn't even tell you right from left.  We scoured the menu and I came across the love of my life. Artichokes. Yes ladies and gents, I will take a nice artichoke over ALOT of things. So that was to be my appetizer paired with my main course of Potato Gnnochis (hey, I was trying to see if I could do veggie for a week).   First off, the artichokes were sent from heaven. The leaves were sooooooo juicy and tender that you can almost eat it like a muffin. My only complaint was that they were a tad garlicky. Once I pounded that out, I got started on my gnocchi's. They were pan-seared with asparagus, onions, etc. This was soooo good that it made the NY guineas I was with blush. The food, bless it's heart, was splendid.  Now on to the ambience of the place. It's a very clean, trendy restaurant. The crowd (not sure if it was just that night) was a little strange. Let's just say, I saw a 55 year old guy with a pony-tail kiss 6 different call-girls as they came strolling in one at a time. How did I know they were call girls you ask? Well, they all had slammin bodies, but their faces look kind of busted. Plus they were wearing outfits straight out of J-Wow's closet.  Any, this place is pretty LBD. On my LBD scale, it has to be an 8 trending to a 9. If I went back, I'd probably just order the same thing because it was THAT GOOD.  Holla.

AJ4CTGMsz46s0Lcv_FtB8Q.text: My husband and I were here for their "bar bites" (happy hour) menu before going to an exhibit at the nearby Mint Museum uptown. I think everything on the bar bites menu was $5 (food) and there were drink specials as well. In NC, sadly, we can't really enjoy happy hour (it's illegal to sell drinks at a discount for a set window within a day - you can have specials on drinks, but they must be offered all day...). Like most bar bites and happy hour menus, you have to eat in the bar to get the special. We were promptly greeted by the bartender who poured filtered water from a bottle (tap water basically) into our glasses. She was very friendly, and gave us the time we needed to look over the menu. Tip: the happy hour or bar bite menu is tucked in the back of the cocktail menu.  We ordered the calamari (small portion and average at best), the lamb sliders (you get two, they're served with delicious goat cheese, some kind of lettuce/green, and homemade thin-sliced pickles - yum), and two orders of the truffle oil gnocchi! We got two orders because my husband had tried them here before (they're offered as an appetizer for much more) and insisted we get two. Thank goodness we did - I don't think I would have shared. This was far and away the highlight of our options! Crazy-delicious. Usually, anything cooked with truffles or truffle oil is great, but the texture was almost airy-pillowy, they were perfectly cooked and seasoned and were served with some thin slices of fresh and deliciously salty prosciutto.   We will definitely come back, but we'll just jump to the gnocchi! My husband got a glass of Woodford reserve on the rocks - $14 - not cheep at all, but not an uncommon price or markup. The entrees of the nearby customers looked great too. The restaurant is big (with an upstairs area) and is nicely decorated without being stuffy. I went in wearing jeans and felt fine... I visited the ladies room, which I only note because the floor was oddly super sticky - my shoes stuck with each step.   Overall, I give it 5 stars. Great location, good service and quality food. I believe they also offer free valet, but we didn't use it because we got there before 6pm (the city of CLT doesn't let the valet companies set up before 6PM due to traffic flow). We parked in the underground deck "the greens" for $5.   Hope this review was useful. Enjoy - and don't forget to get the gnocchi!!!! Also see my attached pictures...

6pa2XzYoOPzMECCV_0PqFw.text: We are staying uptown overnight to celebrate my daughter's 8th birthday. After getting the runaround at Carolina Ale House, the four children and I walked down to Aria. I hesitated, given that it's clearly a lovely restaurant, but we were graciously welcomed and given the "chef's table" when I asked for somewhere unobtrusive where we wouldn't disturb anyone. The birthday girl is a budding chef and was thrilled to watch the kitchen at work. Our server, Justin, was gracious and kind to all of us and even put together a special dinner for the tiny guest who doesn't like Italian.   Turns out this little one inhaled every plate that came to our table. From the cannellini bean salad presented with the bread to the caprese to the risotto, each dish was delicious and our young guests declared themselves ruined for any other pizza or pasta.   We left stuffed and happy and the kids had an evening that is now a shared wonderful experience. We will absolutely be back!

ny3fBm7lM5L4AoPKZ5aoZQ.text: Like several places in Uptown, the address listed is sure to confuse because you really cant get to the restaurant by 100 N. Tryon. Better to call ahead and get the low down on the Best way to get in. We got rerouted walking through the building several times and it was a little annoying.  The place was packed as most of the diners seemed to be going to the show at the Blumenthal (as we were). This would be a challenge I am sure as everyone arrives at similar times, but everyone wants to go at nearly exactly the same time. However, that must be a regular challenge for the restaurant so I certain they train their folks on the most efficient way to manage that. Which brings me to my point. Training.  Our server was very nice, but I think there is a little more work that can be done to develop your servers to represent the brand. We asked for a wine recommendation and she said she didn't know anything about wine. Hm. Missed opportunity to create some interest to turn a glass of wine into a bottle or stimulate some conversation in that direction. She said she would ask the bar person to pick something out. In a few minutes a man came and dropped of a glass of wine with no comment. My friend did not know what kind of wine it was and no one checked back to ask if it was okay until the meal was over. The food was...okay. We got the octopus appetizer special. It look more like calamari with the little tentacles etc. I am accustomed to getting a thicker piece of tentacle that you can slice. It was hard to get a real sense of the taste just chewing a tangle of legs. One friend got the pasta with sausage. I got the gnocchi with short rib ragu. The gnocchi was actually very good. Light and airy, it did not feel as heavy as I was a little concerned it may be. The short rib ragu however was extremely salty. My mouth still felt the saltiness an hour later as I was sitting in the theater wishing I had a 2 liter bottle of water. Another friend had the butternut squash ravioli though and it was Best of Show. Absolutely delicious with a brown butter sage treatment. If our other meals were that good, I could almost forgive that it took so long to get a second drink at our table. From the time we wanted one, we tried to get someone's attention for several minutes, then from the time we asked for it, we were finished eating by the time they came. Service just wasnt all that great here tonight. For restaurants that are conveniently located for the theater, I would probably come again as Aria was still so much better than some others close by.

7LgOrHrIMtzjROA72OAzTA.text: Worst customer service I've encountered in a long long time. There is an entrance to the restaurant from the commons area of the Bank of America Corporate Center building in which Aria is located. The restaurant either cannot or won't close off this entrance during business hours. Thus - we had a constant annoying stream of people coming and going to the restaurant during our presentations - some of them talking loudly as they came up the stairs to exit the restaurant.  Secondly, the upstairs room IS NOT isolated from the rest of the restaurant - the stairway and some open space allow a lot of noise to filter upstairs. The second presenter had to move away from the podium right up to the group so that he could be heard (microphone was not working).  I'm not going to ding Aria about the meeting space issues as I had no hand in booking the space. Decor was really nice, clean and simple. Thankfully being that there were a few local events happening that night, finding a seat at 8:30pm was easy (despite not having reservations). I opted for the bar, which ultimately was a mistake.   Service (for me) was lacking! One seat a way was a couple who I imagine had some affiliation to the restaurant (i.e.; owner, frequent patron, friend of the owner, etc.). Everyone... chefs, servers, managers, other diners at the bar and those working the bar seemed so engrossed with their every need. Before their glasses of wine was done bartenders were waiting to pour more. They received great treatment, but as a result it unfortunately seemed that I (a paying diner) was an afterthought.   I had to call the bartender over so I could order a drink. When my glass of water finished, no one offered a refill. When my cocktail was done, not once did anyone check if I wanted to order another. Even complimentary bread (which others received) wasn't offered. Upon finishing my meal, I wasn't asked if I'd like to see a dessert menu. rc9cGdCryxrf5ij7FORYuQ.text: My Wife and I went here this week for her birthday and were not disappointed!  We decided to try two appetizers and a pasta to get a good variety.  We went with the Bruschetta Caponata and the Eggplant Parm al Forno for the apps.  The bruschetta was just eh; okay to eat but would not order again (it had ricotta and olives on sesame toast).  The eggplant on the other hand was fantastic; it also came with a small side salad with peppadew peppers and I could have eaten an entire plate of the salad alone.  Cannot recommend the eggplant appetizer enough.   The pasta we ordered was the Pasta al Nero it came with lump crab, mussels and colossal shrimp in a spicy (but not too spicy) red sauce.  Do not be scared off by the $25 price tag- it is worth every penny if not more.  I will be going back to Aria for this pasta alone!  The atmosphere inside was nice but not too stuffy/intimidating.  The staff was very friendly and we told the waitress we were going to be sharing everything and they divided all of our orders in two plates when bringing everything out.  We also had the Mojito Italiano which was a fun twist on the mojito and will def order again!

iZYQJ8LoEU1vNQ7IIwADBQ.text: In town for the Game of Thrones Live? The only logical place to eat before the show is Aria.   But really, we obviously hit a local favorite. The hostess informed us the bar was open seating so we jumped in while we could.   The bar Staff was attentive, even though we only had one glass of wine between the two of us. Within 10 minutes of us sitting down, the place was FILLED. There were customers standing to eat, in the waiting area, all tables were full, etc. We arrived at the perfect time.   We skipped on the appetizers since we saw some delicious sounding deserts. She ordered the salmon and I ordered the Kale salad and butternut squash Ravioli.  The Salad was great, it was a lot bigger than I was expecting and was dressed really well.   Our entrees tasted really great too. The portions were pretty small though. My ravioli came with 7 or 8 pieces. The taste almost made up for it, it literally tasted like a holiday meal all in one plate.   Her salmon was about half the size of most places, but she really enjoyed it.   After our entrees we had to try the Tiramisu. It was pretty awesome. You could tell it was homemade. Thick mascapone with a heavy espresso kick with the lady fingers. Again, the serving size was really small, it's hard to get the full experience of the deserts if you are sharing them.  Overall, Arial was a good experience. The Staff was great, bathrooms were clean, and the food tasted good.  The negatives: To appear as a romantic restaurant, it gets really loud, even away from the bar area. The food portions are really small for the high prices.  For a salad, two entrees, desert, and a glass of wine I paid $73 after tip. Would I visit again? Maybe if I am in  Charlotte with a larger budget.

IAluH9yhpjDO69QBln1KCg.text: Food: 2 - 2.5 stars Decor/Vibe/Service: 3.5 - 4 stars  After my second trip here for dinner last night, I have to echo the general theme of reviews for Aria: cool vibe, great decor, really average food (at best). I also have to echo the desire to want to like this place, because I really do...it's a bummer that the food's just so mediocre.   That said, I've specifically been disappointed by:     -  The wine list: yes, they do offer a wide variety, but their by the glass selection is much less diverse. I realize it's an Italian restaurant (and so my desire for a sweeter/less dry white may fall on deaf ears) but it would be nice if they offered something on that end by the glass (not a glass of Riesling, Gruner Veltliner or Semillon to be seen...although they did offer bottles of each of these).       -  The Pork Chop with Brussels Sprouts, Caramelized Apple, Mustard Balsamic Sauce: all around, I was just bored by this dish. The balsamic sauce gave the apples a little bit of a weird flavor, and the pork chop was either not cooked very well or was just not a good pork chop to begin with...not sure which. And the Brussels sprouts...where do I begin? I'm currently in the midst of a love affair with this vegetable, so believe me when I say I've tried them at more than a few restaurants in various cities over the past year or two. I've now been severely disappointed by them twice at Aria, and will NOT be ordering them again. Usually, Brussels sprouts in restaurants blow my home-made versions out of the water (much to my chagrin), but the chef at Aria saw fit to overcook and under season them, for reasons that I cannot fathom.    - The Chocolate Hazelnut Cake with Hazelnut Gelato & Vanilla Cream: A few Yelpers were big fans of this dessert, but I found it very...blah. The gelato was super whatever, and the cake was...just cake. It wasn't bad at all, and I do think the texture was good...moist and everything. But I seriously had no desire to finish it, which is unusual for me as I'm normally the "lick the dessert plate clean" type.   Also had the Penne a la Vodka, which was fine but again nothing to write home about.   The one thing that I will say was legitimately good and I would order again is the Mascarpone Cheesecake with Strawberry Sauce; if feel the need to come to Aria despite what you've read here on Yelp, get this dessert, because it might be the only good thing you have all evening. The mascarpone cheese just gives it this divine texture...yum. But seriously, I would save your $$ and skip Aria altogether.

-5KaRpakSjnm_e0eH7SVog.text: Aria has just opened within the last week or two, but it has none of that clumsy new-restaurant feeling. Being part of the Sonoma Restaurant Group they must have drawn on the experience of Press, Sonoma, and Pie Town to pull off a flawless opening. Upon first entering and confirming our reservation the maitre d' politely whisked our coats off to the coat check. That's the sort of thing than sometimes slips at a new place, but was very much appreciated.  The decor was modern but comfortable, with low-backed white leather chairs abound. Outside was Charlotte's first snowstorm of the year, and inside felt as cozy as you could want. Our waitress hurried over immediately with menus, a wine list, and a bottle of water. Very prompt. We decided on a bottle of wine, and dithered over our food choices. The waitress checked back with us several times to see if we were ready, but it never felt like she was rushing us. We actually ordered (and received) our appetizers before deciding on our main course - an unusual route - but she was fine with it.  I used to think that all the world's bruschetta should be like the little Italian place I used to visit as a kid, but I've learned that every restaurant does it differently. At Aria, it was VERY different. The thickly sliced bread was covered with olives and thick ricotta cheese - nothing like what I had expected, but fantastic all the same.  Our main courses, once we had chosen them, were just as good. Being a bit of a pig, I ordered both a pasta course (Primi) and a meat course (Secondi). My girlfriend, wisely, had only one. I started with the risotto, which was richer than I ever imagined. The goat cheese was intensely awesome, and I started regretting my decision to order two entrees. But then the salmon came out and my regrets evaporated. It's so hard to find good (non-fried) fish in Charlotte, and these guys nailed it. Medium-rare grilled salmon on a bed of even more risotto. I had dreams about it that night.  So we loosened our belts, paid our bill, and picked up our unfinished bottle of wine. The dinner may have ended, but we still had plans. I had heard that there was a lounge upstairs, and we wanted to check it out. We scooted up the stairs at the back of the restaurant and found a lounge that looked exactly like the restaurant below. This is where Aria's newness became evident. They had envisioned the upstairs "lounge" as a semi-separate bar - it has a different name printed on its windows - but it wasn't drawing in any business on its own. Part of the problem may have been the very accessible bar downstairs with the main restaurant, which I found to be more inviting. We felt sort of abandoned upstairs on our own. If it were busier that would help, but it would take a lot of people to fill such a large space. Also, bizarrely, the upstairs bar opened onto the brightly lit but thoroughly closed Founder's Hall of the Hurst Tower. I guess they hope to bring in the banking lunch crowd, but at night it was like drinking in an abandoned shopping mall. When they sort out their vision of the upstairs bar, I'll revise this review - likely to 5 stars.
